segments.text: The birth rate among middle-class Negroes is much less than it is among middle-class whites.
So you're going back to Harvard, Dan, to continue this work in the fall?
Right, and come back here again in the spring.
After your 66th birthday, you have to retire from administrative jobs at Harvard.
You could continue to teach on a half-time basis for four years until you're 70.
I'm 67 now.
You were explaining why you were only going to teach half-time?
Oh, yeah.
Oh, yeah.
So I'm teaching there in the fall semester and here at UCSD in the spring.
When you come back to UCSD, what sort of courses do you offer?
Well, my new professorship is professor of science and public policy, the kind of professorship that old professors have.
I don't know much science anymore.
And the course I taught, I taught an undergraduate course this spring called Technology in the Poor Countries, which I talked about.
And in Harvard, I teach a course, undergraduate course, called Human Population to Natural Resources.
And I have a group of graduate students who are getting their doctorate degrees.
And I take part in three or four other courses and population courses that are given under the auspices of the Center for Population Studies.
But the only course I'm solely responsible for is this big undergraduate course.
Now, I now have a series of questions and comments I'd like for you to make up on various things that you've done or things you've said in your career.
First, the Capricorn expedition.
Well, was the major purpose of the Capricorn expedition to measure heat loss?
Heat flow, you mean?
Heat flow, right.
No.
Like all these, like most of these big expeditions, it was to, it was, it had several purposes, but the principal purpose was the geology and geophysics of the
of the deep sea floor of the Pacific.
And we studied that basically in four or five different ways.
One was by the main concern.
That was the seismic refraction studies, which
which basically gave the depth of sediments, the depth of what's called the second layer, and the depth to the Mohorovic discontinuity.
And some idea about the sound velocity.
In fact, a good idea about the sound velocity in these different layers.
The second was deep sea sounding.
And Bill Menard and Bob Fisher were in charge of it.
that part of the operation.
We were particularly interested here in the Tonga Trench, which is one of the great deeps, oceanic deeps of the world.
It may even be the deepest, although there are four deeps that are just about the same depth, the Mindanao Trench, the Marianas Trench, the Tonga Trench, and the Kuril Trench.
And we wanted to find out
what its shape was, what it actually looked like.
Because Bob Fisher particularly had developed a hypothesis that new trenches would be V-shaped in cross-section, have practically no sediments in them, whereas old trenches would have a flat bottom.
The U-shape would be U-shaped.
Not necessarily old trenches, but trenches that had
A very considerable sediment source nearby would have a flat bottom, and the sediments would accumulate in them.
And of course, it turned out that the Tonga Trench was B-shaped, flat B.
And the other part of the job of studying the trench was, what were the sediments like?
And what sediments there were were practically all volcanic there.
And this was, as you might expect, because only the very youngest sediments were still there.
The others were being carried down into the crust of the Earth.
And the problem of how deep it was and how variable the depth was, one of the interesting discoveries was a great seamount on the side of it.
of the trench, of the volcano that had been carried down into the trench.
It was already several hundred meters deep.

We were interested in one of the other interesting things we did was to look at a place called Alexa Bank, which is north of the Fiji Islands, between the Fiji Islands and the Marianas Islands, or the Marshall Islands, which was a sunken atoll.
An atoll that never recovered after the Pleistocene.
The top of it is about 100, 200 people over the surface.
And we had divers, scuba divers, who went down and looked at this.
It's just a typical atoll, but one which was never able to build up as fast as the water rose.
And the result was that it's now a fossil atoll.
So another thing that we were interested in was the bottom, was the topography of what was called

what is now called the Easter Island Rise, the mid-ocean ridge in the South Pacific, which continues all the way into the Gulf of California, and California itself is really part of the Easter Island Rise, separated with what we now call the Pacific Plate from the American Plate, the North American Plate.
Another thing was, of course, the measurement of the heat flow.
We'd already measured that on the mid-pack exposition in the area between the Marshall Islands and the Hawaiian Islands.
We got a lot more measurements on Capricorn.
And another, Ronald Mason was on board.
And his interest was in making magnetic surveys, essentially towing the magnetometer
and then making magnetic surveys around some of the South Pacific atolls.
We were also very much interested in the sediments that we had.
We took a lot of long quarters.
And we had a new tool, a new toy, if you will.
We had a huge winch that was capable of getting to the bottom of the Tawny Trench.
This winch didn't work very well.
It was like a fishing wheel that overruns.
It would get out of control, and then the wire would get snarled, badly snarled.
And this happened to us before we went to Fiji, and we spent quite a bit of time in Fiji getting the wire spliced and the winch refitted.
It happened again to us in the Tonga Trench, and we had about 30,000 feet of cable over the side.
It's a tapered cable, small at the outer end, big at the inner end.
Because otherwise, the cable wouldn't hold its own weight in those great depths.
And this was one of the worst days I ever spent in my life.
The wire got badly kinked.
And so what we had to do was to cut it and remove the kinked portion and then splice it together again.
And we had about, I don't know, six or seven tons
weight hanging over the ship and the A-frame and the stern of the ship.
This was on the Horizon.
Horizon was the one that had the big wind.
Not the Horizon, I'm sorry, Spencer F. Baird.
Horizon was the two-ship expedition, Horizon and Spencer F. Baird.
It took 24 hours to do this.
And at all the time, you were afraid something was going to slip.
and put wire clamps on the bitter end, the outer end of the cable, and have enough room at the back of this clamp so that you could splice it, so you could make a long splice.
Very painful, difficult process with three-quarters cable.
But anyhow, he did it and brought it out.
And we used the wedge after that quite successfully.
That was the last time that the goddamn thing fell.
Gosh, what an awful.
It would have been, we gradually learned in the oceanographic business to handle heavier and heavier weights, more and more massive equipment.
And that's, of course, the ultimate
The result of this is this huge Glomar Challenger, which stores 100 tons of pipe in the bottom.
So the sediments, the heat flow, the bottom topography, the magnetic measurements, looking at shallow water features like Falcon Bank, which
volcano that gets cleaned off.
In a few years, every time it erupts, and it creates a pile of volcanic debris several hundred feet high.
It's an island.
It then gets washed away by the waves.
And in between eruptions, it's about 50 feet deep, or at least 25 feet deep.
I remember we were very touchy about going on
approaching Stalkin Island, and we were afraid we might go and drown.
I remember Art Maxwell coming up to me and saying, we're aground.
And what had happened was we backed up, and we were getting the bubbles from our own weight.
morning ground, thank God.
We did a lot of work in the islands, like in the Beattie Islands, a lot of topography in shallow water.
We started out from Bikini, or from Quagmire, from Bikini, actually, where both ships had been involved in one of the
one of the big hydrogen bomb tests.

And then went from there to the Fiji Islands, and the Fijis to the Tonga Islands, and the Tongas to Tahiti, and Tahiti to the Tuamotus, and from the Tuamotus to the Marquesas, and then home across the eastern North Pacific.
All together lasted about four months.
I remember we spent Christmas in the Tonga Islands.
And we had many subsidiary projects.
For example, one of the most interesting things about high islands in the Pacific, like some of the Tonga Islands, is that there's a notch cut just in the tidal zone.
These are limestone islands.
And you get erosion of the limestone in the intertidal zone.
The profile of the island would be a cliff like this, cut back like this, and then a reef out here.
And what in the world causes that?
Nobody really knows what causes it.
Because the ocean is super saturated, the surface ocean water is super saturated with calcium carbonate.
But apparently in the intertidal zone, you have sufficient biological activity so that the pH is lowered part of the time.
by organic production of CO2 and organic production of organic acids, which allows the calcium carbonate to dissolve.
Walter Monk was on the expedition.
Bill Menard, Bill Riedel, Bob Fisher, Russ Ray, Helen Ray was on it.
She joined us in Tonga and went the rest of the way with us.
We had most of the best top Iranians.
I think was on board, too.
I'm sure he was.
We had most of the geologists and geophysicists of the Scripps Institution on this expedition.
And it was a, we didn't really learn
as much from that expedition as we did from mid-pack, which was the first one of our expeditions.
But it was there that the rust rays definitely showed that the sediments were very thin, and our heat flow measurements showed that the heat flow was very high.
But we learned a lot about the trench, and that was perhaps the most important thing.
We did a bit of work on the trenches off the American coast.
the Acapulco Trench and the Peru-Chile Trench.
And we learned a good deal about the South Pacific deep sea sediments.
And gradually, over the years, we had a series of expeditions like this.
Capricorn was the only two that I led, but we had a lot of others led by the other people that I described yesterday.
And I think we contributed very fundamentally to the ideas of sea floor spreading and plate tectonics.
I guess the most significant thing that we did
as it turned out, was the work that Ronald Mason did right off the California coast.
He wanted to make a magnetic, using this towed magnetometer that Victor Wacky invented during World War II, he wanted to make a magnetic survey.
The coast geodetic survey was at that time making a topographic survey of the sea floor up to 200 or 300 miles off California.
Ron thought it would be a good idea to make a magnetic survey at the same time as this topographic survey is being made.
And I thought it would too, although I didn't quite know why.
But it was a new geophysical tool that was bound to show something.
And what he found when he worked up the data was that the remnant magnetism had a very
Well, it had a remarkable pattern.

It had a pattern of long stripes of high and low magnetic field, of ridges, magnetic ridges that would be 100 miles long or so, 150 miles long, and then separated by magnetic look, by magnetic valleys, if you will, ridge and valley structure and contiguous series of these things.
These were cut by what Bill Menard called fracture zones.
And they didn't continue across the fracture zones.
Later, Victor Boffier and Arthur Roth continued this work.
And they showed that, in fact, the whole pattern of Richardson Cross was displaced on the two sides of a fracture zone by distances up to several hundred kilometers.
It wasn't a lot.
Well, that was really the real confirmation of the ideas of movement of plates of the sea floor.
And it was later that people in England got the idea that these magnetic stripes were alternately
dikes of volcanic rock that were coming up along the mid-ocean ridges and moving across the ocean floor to the edges of the plates.
That's the notion of sea floor spreading, which is one of the basic concepts of plate tectonics.
The ocean floor was continually being renewed along the mid-ocean ridge and continually moving toward the edges of the ocean basin.
Bob Fisher and I wrote a paper.
which we call the trenches of the Pacific, about 1954, I guess, in which we analyzed the remarkable features of the trenches.
And it seemed quite clear to us that there must be downward movement under the trenches.
And that's what we said, in fact.
And the reason was that they had
no sediment in them.
They had negative gravity anomalies.
They had very low heat flow.
And this meant that if you had a downward force acting downward to pull the rock down and to cool it off, pull the heat down.
Whereas in the mid-ocean ridge, there was an upward moving
arm of a convection cell, believe it or not, you had a high heat flow over the ridges.
And that was what Martin Maxwell had found on a later expedition to the eastern South Pacific.
Over the Easter Island rise, there was high heat flow intermediate between the ridge and the trench and very low heat flow over the trench or near the trench.

And then we wrote a paper, Maxwell and Bullard and I wrote a paper on the measurements of heat cells, in which we said we couldn't explain these in any other way than by huge convection cells in the mantle rising along the ridges and sinking along the trenches, and that the rock was being carried along the sea floor from the ridge to the trench.
We didn't have the wit to...

make the connection between this process and this magnetic striking, which in fact occurs all over the ocean, all over the deep sea, which is the clearest evidence there is of that movement of the bottom of the ocean floor away from the ridges and toward the trenches, or toward the continental boundary.
This, of course, also explains why there's so little sediment.
It had previously been thought that there must be thousands of feet of sediment, of the deep sea sediments, which had been accumulating since the beginning of geologic time.
It turned out there were only about 100 meters of sediment in much of the sea floor.
And nobody could possibly figure out
say that this had been accumulated since the beginning of geological time.
It just wasn't anywhere near enough of it.
Something must have been getting our set of them.
What was getting them was that they were moving away into the trenches and being carried down into the interior of the Earth.
And nobody has ever found anything on the ocean floor older than about mid-potation, about 150 million years old.
Our mid-pack expedition, we found on the tops of these deep,
6,000-foot seamounts of shallow water fossils, which were about 100 million years old, late Cretaceous.
That was another indication that the ocean floor was very young.
All these phenomena had occurred just in the last really few minutes of geologic time.
I've thought for a while that maybe the explanation for the
deep seamounts was that the volume of the ocean had increased a lot in the last 100 million years.
But I think Bill Menard gave the true explanation, and that was that the seamounts formed on the ridges, the volcanoes on the ridge, and then moved down the slope from the ridge to the deep sea.
And they just gradually got deeper and deeper as they went further from the ridge.
When you say increase in the volume of the ocean, is that when you suggest that the Pacific seabed dropped drastically 100 million years ago?
Or sometimes.
Sometimes.
Not 100 million years.
Within the last 100 million years.
I don't think that that's certainly not a, probably not a correct explanation, and certainly not a necessary explanation.
I think it's more likely that what happened is that the volcano simply moved into deeper water.
They were in shallow water.
Their tops were at the surface, planed off at the surface, and moved into water that was about 6,000 feet deeper.
And their tops are therefore now 6,000 feet deep.
But they're planed off, retaining the shallow water character.
And the atolls formed the same way.
The only difference being the atolls moved slowly enough so that coral reef animals could keep up with the sinking.
Whereas these deep sea mounds, these gills, apparently moved too fast before the corals could get started or could really maintain themselves.
We have a remarkable collection of people who were working on these different aspects of the geology and geophysics.
Russ Rade and George Shore, Art Maxwell and Dick Von Herzen, Art Roth, Ronald Mason, Victor Bacchier, Gustav Arrhenius, Ed Goldberg, Henry Roche, and later, Pam Craig and Hans Seuss.
And then the

And that's why I say it was one of the great ages of exploration, because this is when we really found that the ocean floor is quite different in many ways than the continents are, very fundamentally different than the continents.
It's quite obvious now with this idea of sea floor spreading and that on the sea floor you have
half a dozen features that are unique.
One of them is the seamounts and the atolls.
Another is the trenches.
Another is the mid-ocean ridges.
So another is what are called abyssal plains, absolutely flat plains that extend for hundreds of miles.
These were first discovered by Morris Ewing in Atlanta, but they exist also in the Pacific.

These are due to huge masses of sediment being carried down by density currents from the continental slope and spreading in something like a base surge of Bikini over a very wide area and then settling down.
Still another, which was Bill Menard's major discovery, was the fraction zones, which we now know cut across the
the mid-ocean ridges and displaced them.
The mid-ocean ridges are displaced about every 100 or 200 miles by a fracture zone, which was explained by Tuzo Wilson.
These are trans-current faults.
The problem is what happens at the end of these things, at the end of them.
You have to have sinking or rising of material.
And so they extend all the way to the place where sinking is occurring, the trenches, in other words.
And the whole series, there are a whole lot of them here in the Pacific.
Then they were later discovered in the Atlantic, too.
The difference in the discoveries and who made the discoveries was basically what ocean people were working on in the Atlantic, the mid-ocean ridge.
was a much more clear-cut feature and had this crack down the middle of it, a whole series of cracks, which were places where the lava was rising.
In the Pacific, the Easter Island rise is the same kind of a feature, but a much gentler feature.
It didn't exhibit its mid-ridge crack.
On the other hand, the fracture zones were much more clearly present and easily seen in the Pacific.
And the trenches are almost
not quite, but almost entirely of the city, ocean phenomena.
And these were the basic building blocks of the theory of seafloor spreading and the theory of plate tectonics.
And I guess I think the credit for the actual
Putting things together, the synthesis belongs to a series of people, a group of people, none of whom are in scripts.
Bob Dietz, who was here as a graduate, took his PhD here, but later worked with Noah, and Harry Hess at Princeton, and a couple of guys at Cambridge, England.
Matthews and Drummond.
So Drummond, Matthews, and the name of the other one.
I don't remember who they were, but Matthew was one of them.
Neither Ewing, who did a tremendous amount of actual data gathering in the sea, nor we, really had the imagination to put it all together, as we did.
Seaboard spreaders and plate tectonics people did.
